query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: One study in the USA found that a greater number of little brown bats infected with white-nose syndrome survived in hibernation chambers at 4°C than at 10°C (1013). The same study also found that infected little brown bats stayed in hibernation for longer in hibernation chambers at 4°C than at 10°C (1013). Two studies have evaluated the effects of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium for white-nose syndrome (2008). One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic at the time of infection increased survival and reduced disease symptoms in a laboratory setting. However, the same study found that bats treated 21 days prior to infection had worse symptoms (2008). A randomized, controlled study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic in a mine increased the survival of free-flying bats, but not of caged bats (2008). The same study found that the severity of white-nose syndrome in caged bats was similar to that of untreated bats(2008). There were no studies found that evaluated the effects of culling bats infected with white-nose syndrome on bat populations (1012).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"white-nose syndrome in bats effectiveness of strategies"}

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of modifying hibernacula environments to increase the survival of bats infected with white-nose syndrome. The study was in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Survival (1 study): One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that a greater number of little brown bats infected with the white-nose syndrome fungus survived in hibernation chambers at 4°C than at 10°

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Behaviour change (1 study): One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that little brown bats infected with the white-nose syndrome fungus stayed in hibernation for longer in hibernation chambers at 4°C than at 10°"
}

{
  "action_id": "2008",
  "action_title": "Treat bats for infection with white-nose syndrome",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium to reduce white-nose syndrome infection. One study was in Canada and one in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome (but not 21 days prior) increased survival within cages in a laboratory. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium within a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not caged bats.
Condition (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that little brown bats caged in a laboratory and treated with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome had reduced symptoms of the disease, but bats treated 21 days prior to infection had worse symptoms. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that little brown bats kept within cages in a mine and treated with a probiotic bacterium had a similar severity of white-nose syndrome to untreated bats.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: To mitigate the impact of road and railway developments, what structures can be installed to help bats cross safely?
relevant_summary: A study in the UK found that a green bridge was used by 97% of bats for crossing a road (979). Another study in Switzerland, which was controlled and before-and-after, showed that an artificial hedgerow could be used for commuting by up to a fifth of lesser horseshoe bats in a colony (981). The installation of bat gantries has been studied in both the UK and France. Two replicated studies found that in the UK, fewer bats used the gantries than crossed the road at traffic height, and one gantry was not used at all (978). In France, a temporary bat gantry was used by three species or species groups of bats, but almost half of the bats crossing the road flew over it at different locations (978).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"safe bat crossings for roads and railways"}

One replicated study in France found that a temporary bat gantry was used by three bat species/species groups, but almost half of crossing bats flew over the road at other locations."
